Mr Fontain demanded, in consequence,the adaption of the necessary measures to establish, in the american ports, the equality of treatment in favor of the french properties, coming from this colony, and to restitute to brick Charles the rights removed from this vessel by the collection of the of .
The Present to whom I communicated the letter from Mr. Fontain is disposed now, as it was
div1.ab: Mister Alphonse Sageat, charged with affair of France.
div1.p: at the time of our first correspondance on this subject, to apply, in the biggest extension, the principle of reciprocity that forms one of the bases of the commercial politics of the United States; but, as the application of this principle, beyond the limits prescribed by the Convention of 1822 and the act of Congress to which Mr. Fontain is referring to, is not found to be comprised in the attributions that are conferred upon it the existing legislation, he charged me with telling you that he hastens to profit from the first occasion, after the reunion of Congress, to present to this assemblee the note from Mr. Fontain, and to demand of it to put in measure by the adoption of all legislative disposition that will be necessary in this effect, to satisfy the desire of your government.

In that which concerns the reimbursement of the differential rights removed from the brik Charles, as it resulted in the decision of the Treasury, that, already, was communicated to your legation, that this tax was perceived in virtue of the law, the President did not think to be authorised to demand of Congress the necessary funds for operating this reimbursement.
In another part of his letter, Mr. Fontain

calls for, in the name of his government and in virtue of the principle of reciprocity, the enjoyment his favor of the french properties, coming from Senegal, the assured advantages by the act of 1828, to those coming from Martinique and Guadeloupe, and founds his reclamation on the fact that the american properties that enter in the Port of Gorée are assimilated by the payment of one franc by the barrel by the french properties, coming from foreign contries; and he announces to me to obtain this advantage, your government would be disposed to abolish the differential rights removed from the imported by american properties, and left in of Goree.

On this proposition, several objections presented themselves, even after the revocation of the rights above. First, the admission of american vessels would be limited to the port of Gorée, while the french properties coming from this Port, or from all other points of the Colony would be indistinctly admitted to the United States. Then, in examining the printed resume that accompanies the letter of Mr. Fontain, it seems,by the numbers 8 and 9 of the general "dispositions that the importation of certain products from the United States, and the exportation of certain others, by american properties, are , and, by the table of taxes, that the merchandises imported under the

american flag are sujettes to the rights, quadrupled by those removed from the same merchandises imported by french properties. If this interpretation of the tariff is exact, I do not see how Mr. Fontain can invoke the principle of reciprocity to press the demand of your government. The President does not feel authorised consequently, to submit it to the consideration of Congress. But he gave me the order to assure you that when your government judges it to be appropriate to put the commerce between the United States and the Ports of Senegal on a foot of perfect reciprocity, it will be a pleasure to recommend to Congress the adoption of corresponding measures, on the part of the United States.
I seize this occasion. Signed John Forsyth
